stem: The nurse is caring for a client with type 1 diabetes mellitus who was admitted for hyperglycemia. Based on the provided electronic health record (EHR) information, match each insulin type with its expected onset of action.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
10/26/2026 07:00
S: Mr. Jones reports feeling thirsty and states, "I think my blood sugar is high again."
B: 68-year-old male with a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Admitted for hyperglycemia. Home medications include: Lispro 5 units before meals, Insulin Glargine 20 units at bedtime, Metoprolol 50mg BID, and Atorvastatin 40mg daily. Last Glargine dose was at 22:00.
A: Blood glucose trending upward. Currently 320 mg/dL. Patient alert and oriented x3. Denies chest pain, shortness of breath, or abdominal pain. Urine positive for ketones.
R: Will administer 5 units Lispro per sliding scale. Check blood glucose in 1 hour. Encourage oral fluid intake. Contact provider if blood glucose remains elevated after Lispro administration. Monitor for signs and symptoms of DKA. 
10/26/2026 08:00
S: Reports feeling slightly better after insulin.
O: Blood glucose 280 mg/dL. Continue to monitor.
10/26/2026 09:00
S: Blood glucose 200 mg/dL. Patient reports feeling much better. Denies any new complaints.
O: Alert and oriented. Consuming breakfast well.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
- Monitor blood glucose every hour.
- Administer Lispro insulin per sliding scale (Blood glucose 251-300 mg/dL: 4 units, 301-350 mg/dL: 5 units, >350 mg/dL: Call provider).
- Encourage oral fluid intake (2-3 liters per day).
- Monitor urine for ketones every shift.
- Administer Insulin Glargine 20 units subcutaneously at 22:00 daily.
- Metoprolol 50mg PO BID
- Atorvastatin 40mg PO daily

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
Lispro 5 units SubQ 10/26/2026 07:05
Insulin Glargine 20 units SubQ 10/25/2026 22:00

rationale.correct: Lispro is a rapid-acting insulin analog with an onset of action of 15-30 minutes, allowing for administration immediately before meals. Insulin Glargine is a long-acting insulin with an onset of action of 1-2 hours and no pronounced peak, providing basal insulin coverage over 24 hours. The nurse's notes indicate the client received Lispro at 07:05, which aligns with its rapid onset to manage postprandial hyperglycemia.
rationale.incorrect: Selecting other options would be incorrect because they do not align with the known pharmacokinetic profiles of Lispro and Glargine. For instance, Lispro does not have an onset of 1-2 hours or no peak. Glargine does not have an onset of 15-30 minutes, 3-4 hours, or a pronounced peak.

answerBreakdown.rationale: Lispro is a rapid-acting insulin, and rapid-acting insulins have a very fast onset (15-30 minutes) and a short duration.
Insulin Glargine is a long-acting insulin. Long-acting insulins have a delayed onset (1-2 hours), and no peak.

clinicalPearls: Always verify insulin types and dosages with another nurse to prevent medication errors.
Educate clients about the importance of consistent meal timing when using rapid-acting insulins to avoid hypoglycemia.
Rotate insulin injection sites to prevent lipohypertrophy and maintain consistent absorption.

questionTrap.trap: Students often confuse the onset, peak, and duration of different insulin types, especially rapid-acting and short-acting insulins.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Create a chart comparing the onset, peak, and duration of each insulin type and practice identifying them in clinical scenarios. Pay close attention to the timing of insulin administration in relation to meals.

mnemonic.title: LAG
mnemonic.expansion: LAG (Long-Acting = Glargine). Glargine's onset is Longer, and it lasts all day, so it has no peak.
